question: [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: ServiceInfo] [Info Type Mismatch] If address is set but info is None (lines 2583-2584), does this represent an invalid service configuration that should be rejected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamInfo::visit_map] [Active Streams Overflow] Can an attacker register unlimited active_streams (line 2671) to exhaust memory and prevent legitimate indexers from establishing connections? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamInfo] [Stream ID Collision] Does the system validate uniqueness of stream IDs in active_streams, or can duplicate IDs cause data corruption when routing messages to streams? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamInfo::deserialize] [Empty Streams Ambiguity] If active_streams is empty (line 2676), does this mean no streams are active or that stream tracking is disabled, and can this be exploited? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamProgress::visit_map] [Samples Array DoS] Can an attacker provide millions of progress samples (line 2762) to cause memory exhaustion when the entire progress history is loaded? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamProgress] [Sample Order Validation] Are samples expected to be ordered by timestamp/version, and can out-of-order samples cause incorrect progress calculation or rate limiting bypasses? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamProgress::deserialize] [Empty Samples Interpretation] If samples array is empty (line 2767), does this mean no progress or complete progress, and can this ambiguity be exploited? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamProgressSampleProto::visit_map] [Version Monotonicity Violation] Does StreamProgressSampleProto validate that version increases monotonically across samples (line 2881), or can version rollbacks be used to falsify progress metrics? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamProgressSampleProto] [Size Bytes Overflow] Can extremely large size_bytes values (line 2889) cause integer overflow when calculating bandwidth or storage metrics, leading to incorrect resource accounting? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: StreamProgressSampleProto::serialize] [Zero Values Omission] When version or size_bytes are 0 (lines 2785-2788), they're not serialized - can this cause receivers to interpret missing fields incorrectly? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionRootFilter::visit_map] [Transaction Type Enum Bypass] In line 3002, can providing an invalid transaction_type enum value bypass type validation and match unintended transaction types? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionRootFilter::serialize] [Enum Conversion Error] Does the from_i32 conversion at line 2923 properly handle all transaction type values, or can out-of-range values cause serialization to fail silently? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionRootFilter] [Success Filter Bypass] If success field is None (line 2996), does this match both successful and failed transactions, potentially exposing sensitive error data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionsInStorage::visit_map] [Transactions Array Size Attack] Can an attacker provide an extremely large transactions array (line 3105) that exhausts memory when loaded, causing the indexer service to crash? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionsInStorage] [Starting Version Mismatch] Does the system validate that starting_version (line 3112) matches the actual version of the first transaction in the array, or can version misalignment cause data corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionsInStorage::deserialize] [Empty Transactions Array] If transactions array is empty but starting_version is set (lines 3118-3119), does this represent a valid state or an error condition that should be rejected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionsResponse::visit_map] [Chain ID Verification Bypass] Does the client verify that chain_id (line 3234) in the response matches the expected chain, or can cross-chain data injection occur? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionsResponse] [Processed Range Validation] Does the system validate that processed_range (line 3241) covers all transactions in the transactions array, or can partial processing be hidden? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: TransactionsResponse::deserialize] [Response Size DoS] Can servers send responses with millions of transactions (line 3227) to overwhelm clients with large messages, causing memory exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: UserTransactionFilter::visit_map] [Sender Address Spoofing] Does the sender field (line 3345) validate that addresses are properly formatted and not system addresses, or can attackers filter for privileged transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: UserTransactionFilter] [Payload Filter Complexity] Can combining sender filters with complex payload_filter (line 3351) cause exponential matching complexity that enables DoS attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: UserTransactionFilter::deserialize] [Both Fields None] If both sender and payload_filter are None (lines 3356-3357), does this match all user transactions, potentially exposing sensitive data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: UserTransactionPayloadFilter::visit_map] [Entry Function Wildcard] If entry_function_filter is None (line 3449), does this match all entry function payloads, and can this be exploited to extract data from restricted modules? (High)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: UserTransactionPayloadFilter] [Filter Scope Bypass] Can attackers use None filters to bypass module-level access controls and query transactions they shouldn't have visibility into? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.indexer.v1.serde.rs] [Struct: UserTransactionPayloadFilter::deserialize] [Missing Payload Type Validation] Does the filter handle non-entry-function payloads (scripts, multisig) correctly, or can type confusion occur? (Medium)
